Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Situation2: Two travelers with several suitcases ask for help loading and plan to split the fare
Story:
I was just finishing my coffee when my phone buzzed. It was Mark, an old acquaintance, asking if I could help him move a few boxes to his new apartment. He sounded a bit desperate, and I knew he didn’t have many people to call. I wanted to say yes—after all, that’s what friends, or even just decent acquaintances, do. But as I was about to reply, two travelers approached my cab, each dragging heavy suitcases. They looked tired and relieved to see me, and immediately asked if I could help them load their bags and take them to the train station, mentioning they’d split the fare.

I could feel the pressure mounting. Mark was counting on me for support, and I didn’t want to let him down. At the same time, as a taxi driver, I was expected to provide prompt, professional service to my customers, and these travelers clearly needed help. My mind raced, torn between the pull of personal loyalty and the demands of my job. I stood there, phone in hand, glancing between the message from Mark and the hopeful faces of the travelers, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in on me.
